case_vignette: A 72-year-old man presents to clinic complaining of 3 months of weight loss, epigastric pain after meals, diarrhea, and acholic stools. On physical exam he has jaundice and a right upper quadrant mass, but no abdominal tenderness. He has a palpable left supraclavicular node. He also has multiple tender areas of inflamed skin on his chest wall and legs. The patient states that these patches change location over time. CT scan of his abdomen is seen in Figure A.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing weight loss, stomach pain after eating, diarrhea, and my stools are light-colored.
Great, thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me more about your age and sex?
I'm a 72-year-old man.

Excellent, thank you for letting me know. Based on the symptoms you've described, can you tell me if you have any history of gastrointestinal conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?
No, I don't have a history of those gastrointestinal conditions.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Have you noticed any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle that could be contributing to your symptoms? For example, have you recently started or stopped taking any medications, or have you made significant changes to your diet?
No, I haven't made any recent changes to my diet or lifestyle that could contribute to my symptoms.

Okay, thank you for clarifying that. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your medical history. Have you ever been diagnosed with any medical conditions, such as diabetes, thyroid disorders, or autoimmune disorders?
I'm sorry, but I don't have any information on my past medical history or any other conditions I may have.
No worries, that's perfectly fine. Can you tell me about any recent travel or exposure to any new foods, medications, or chemicals that could be contributing to your symptoms?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been exposed to new foods, medications, or chemicals.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to perform a physical examination to help determine the cause of your abdominal pain. Can you please lift your shirt and allow me to listen to your abdomen with my stethoscope?
I can tell you that during my actual physical exam, there was no abdominal tenderness.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and physical examination, I would like to order some additional tests to help rule out other potential causes of your abdominal pain. Would you be willing to undergo a CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis?
I've already had a CT scan of my abdomen done.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on the results of your CT scan, I would like to perform a few additional tests to help confirm the diagnosis. Can you please provide a stool sample for analysis? Additionally, I would like to perform an endoscopy to visualize the inside of your digestive tract. Would you be willing to undergo these tests?
Yes, I'm willing to undergo these tests.

Great, thank you for your cooperation. The stool sample will help us rule out infections such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) or infectious diarrhea. The endoscopy will allow us to visualize the inside of your digestive tract and look for any abnormalities such as ulcers, inflammation, or tumors.

After the tests are completed, I will review the results with you and discuss potential treatments options. In the meantime, I recommend that you continue to drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated and avoid any foods that may irritate your stomach.

Is there anything else you would like to know or discuss?
No, there's nothing else I need to know or discuss right now. Thank you.

You're welcome! I'll go ahead and perform the tests as scheduled. If you have any questions or concerns later on, please don't hesitate to reach out to me or your primary care physician.

Also, please make sure to follow any instructions provided by the testing staff during the procedure. They will be able to answer any questions you may have and provide you with any necessary information.

Thank you for entrusting us with your care!
